Award.AwardTitle: IDR: Clinical Ultrafast Laser Microsurgery Probe for Treatment of Scarred Vocal Folds

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1014953
Ben-Yakar

Femtosecond laser microsurgery (FLMS) has emerged as a remarkable technique for precisely ablating living tissue below the surface while ensuring minimal damage to surrounding regions. The combination of this technique with nonlinear optical imaging (NOI) modalities (two-photon fluorescence and second harmonic generation) provides a non-invasive means for visualization to guide laser microsurgeries in situ. A miniaturized probe capable of combined FLMS and NOI will provide physicians a means for guided microsurgery with the highest precision available. The PI proposes to build such a probe specifically designed for use in delicate vocal fold restoration surgeries. They will first determine the required laser parameters for successful creation of sub-surface voids in scarred vocal folds. Second they will build and test an image-guided, miniaturized surgery probe. They will then perform surgery in live animal scar models to determine the efficacy of this novel technique before it can move into clinical trials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chronic voice impairment due to the vocal fold scarring is estimated to affect ~ 4 million Americans. However, there is no reliable treatment for restoring proper phonation to individuals with scarred vocal folds. The Ben-Yakar group at The University of Texas at Austin in collaboration with laryngology experts Dr. Steven Zeitels and Dr. Jim Kobler from Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, have developed a novel laser method that paves the way for scarred vocal fold treatment. Synthetic biomaterials are currently available to recreate the pliability of vocal folds only if they could be injected into scarred and stiffened vocal folds. It is extreme difficulty to inject and localize these biomaterial implants within the scarred tissue, because the injected biomaterials tend to follow the path of least resistance, not necessarily ending up where most needed. To address this challenge, the team has proposed a novel laser treatment method in which an injection space is created inside the scarred tissue precisely where the biomaterial is needed. The researchers use ultrashort pulses (pulses that are millionth of a millionth second) to ablate, namely, vaporize a thin layer tissue below the surface very precisely and then inject the biomaterials directly into the created space.

Ultrafast lasers can be used to achieve remarkable precision during surgical ablation. Thorough nonlinear interactions with tissue, ultrafast lasers can provide a largely non-thermal mechanism of ablation and a unique ability to create targeted surgery within bulk tissue. By using this ultra-precise laser microsurgery method, the Ben-Yakar group has demonstrated successful creation of thin layer of voids below the surface as well as imaging of collagen structures in healthy and scarred tissue samples (Figure 2). They could then inject the biomaterial into the ablated sub-surface voids and successfully localize them within the created space as desired (Figure 3). When injecting without sub surface voids, a back-flow of the injected biomaterial was observed along the point of injection (Fig. 3a), which ultimately prevented localization of the biomaterial at the desired location. In contrast, the presence of sub-surface voids provided a space for the biomaterial, which greatly reduced back-flow at the injection site and resulted in lasting localization of the injected biomaterial (Fig. 3b).


The Ben-Yakar group has also made a great progress to bring this cutting edge technology into clinic through developing fiber-coupled ultrafast laser surgery probes. The first probe (Fig. 4a) demonstrated precise image-guided cellular surgery by imaging fluorescently labeled breast carcinoma cells in cell cultures and then ablating selected single cells (Fig. 4d). The second probe was developed to reduce the overall size of the surgery probe to less than 10 mm in diameter (Fig. 4b). With improved optical design, this probe could image stained and unstained tissue samples (Fig. 4e). The latest probe that the Ben-Yakar group developed offers a further reduction in diameter down to 5 mm (Fig. 4c) and provides an improved microsurgery speed through utilization of a compact, high repetition rate fiber laser. An entire field of view (FOV) could be ablated within 50 ms (Fig. 4f, upper). The Ben-Yakar group also demonstrated ablation of ex-vivo scarred hamster cheek pouches using this probe (Fig. 4f, lower). With further development, this probe can serve as a precise and rapid ultrafast laser scalpel in the clinic.

Overall, this research project demonstrated a new laser microsurgery method that can create sub-surface voids inside scarred tissue and thus enables the localization of biomaterials where they are needed.
